Yes, there have been several specific changes made in response to the Black Lives Matter movement, including:

1. Body Cameras: Many police departments across the United States have started to use body cameras on officers to provide more evidence of their interactions with members of the public.

2. Police Reform Laws: Several states and cities have started to pass police reform packages that include changes like restrictions on chokeholds and other restraints, increased oversight of police departments, and more accountability for officer misconduct.

3. Defunding Police: Some cities have moved to defund police departments and divert funding to social welfare programs and other community-based initiatives.

4. Changes in Prosecution: Several district attorneys have pledged to stop prosecuting certain low-level offenses and focus instead on more serious crimes.

5. Monument Removals: Across the United States, many monuments and statues of Confederate leaders and other figures supporting white supremacy have been removed.

These are just some examples of the changes that have been made as a result of the Black Lives Matter movement. It is important to note that these changes are just the beginning, and more work needs to be done to address the underlying issues of systemic racism and inequality in the United States.
